html:
Alternative forms[edit]

  • poeniō (archaic)

Etymology[edit]

From poena (“punishment, penalty”).

Pronunciation[edit]

  • (Classical) IPA(key): /ˈpuː.ni.oː/, [ˈpuː.n̪i.oː]
  • (Ecclesiastical) IPA(key): /ˈpu.ni.o/, [ˈpuː.ni.ɔ]

Verb[edit]

pūniō (present infinitive pūnīre, perfect active pūnīvī or pūniī, supine pūnītum); fourth conjugation

  1. I punish.
  2. I take vengeance, avenge.

Usage notes[edit]

The passive forms are often treated as a separate deponent verb pūnior, with an active meaning.

Synonyms[edit]

  • (punish): multō

Derived terms[edit]

  • pūnītiō
  • pūnītor

Related terms[edit]

  • poena
  • poenālēs
  • poenālis
  • poenāliter
  • poenārius

Descendants[edit]

  • Italian: punire
  • Old French: punir
    • Middle French: punir
      • French: punir
    • → English: punish
  • Old Occitan: punir
    • Catalan: punir
    • Occitan: punir
  • Piedmontese: punì
  • Portuguese: punir
  • Sardinian: punire
  • Sicilian: puniri
  • Spanish: punir

References[edit]
